description: Magnificent English Baroque church, Grade I listed, gutted by fire in 1941 and restored by Sir Albert Richardson to original design. Many original features. Burial site of Thomas Tallis, organist/choirmaster (1505-85).

factsheet.heading: Historical Associations and Characters
paragraphs: The medieval church on the site had close links with the Tudor dynasty: Henry VIII was baptized here, his sister Mary Rose was married here,  and Thomas Tallis, 'father of English church music', was organist here during the reigns of Henry VIII, Edward VI, Mary I and Elizabeth I.

Samuel Pepys, John Evelyn and Samuel Johnson were occasional worshippers in the church. Revd John Flamsteed, the first Astronomer Royal worshipped here regularly, and there are memorials to other Astronomers Royal: Sir George Biddell Airy and Sir Frank Dyson.
General James Wolfe is buried and commemorated here in an original painting by Edward Penny,  R.A.. General Charles Gordon was baptised here.

factsheet.heading: Architecture and Decoration
paragraphs: The current church building was the first of Nicholas Hawsmoor's London churches, and the first church to be built under the Fifty New Churches Act, providing a template for the others.
The church faces onto Church Street with a Doric east portico, a broken pediment, and drum-shaped 'altars' decorated with putti.
The interior contains what was the largest single unsupported ceiling of its time, providing a sense of space, light and grandeur.

Hawksmoor employed the best artists and craftsmen for the interior: Sir James Thornhill for the trompe l'oeil painting behind the altar; Grinling Gibbons for the woodwork; and Jean Tijou for the altar and gallery railings.
The tower was completed in 1730 by John James of Greenwich.

After the bombing in World War II, Albert Richardson restored the church to its original condition, again employing the best artists and craftsmen: Glyn Jones reconstructed Thornhill's painting; Francis Spear created the stained glass windows; and Augustus Lunn created the egg-tempera mural on the chapel screen in the north-east corner.  Much of Grinling Gibbons' original woodwork survived and salvaged elements were re-incorporated  into the structure.
2019/2020 major conservation work to the roof and stonework and new interpretation themes inside the church

factsheet.heading: History
paragraphs: There has been a church on this site for nearly 1,000 years. It is traditionally the site where St Alfege, Archbishop of Canterbury, was killed by a raiding party of Danes in 1012.
The current church is the third church on the site. The second church, built in the 13th century, had close connections with the Tudor dynasty.
The roof of the second church collapsed in 1710 and the current church was built under the Fifty New Churches Act of 1711. Nicholas Hawksmoor was the architect.
The church was bombed during World War II and was restored to its original condition by Sir Albert Richardson between 1946 and 1953.
The church continues to be a thriving place of worship at the heart of the local community.

factsheet.heading: Restoration
paragraphs: St Alfege Church has recently completed a restoration project supported by the National Lottery

name: St Alfege Church, Greenwich
